heisig_chinese_memo: Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).
heisig_constituent: liver, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, dry, clothesline
koohiiStory1: Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).
koohiiStory2: The slaughterhouse prefers to ship dried liver to the supermarkets (can you imagine boxes soaked in blood on the truck that delivers them?). Imagine them lifting the slabs of flesh and hanging them on the clothesline to dry.
jp_example_words: è‚å¿ƒ(ã‹ã‚“ã˜ã‚“): essential, fundamental, crucial, vital, main
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: If the moon is dry, it's good for your liver! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (ã‹ã‚“) comes out! Right out of your liver.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Genghis Khan glares down at you, "You inherited my liver, and that means no moonshine for you. Protect your liver and don't drink, like me, Genghis Khan."

humanum_full_description_en:
From " meat " to " dry " sound, the original meaning is liver, one of the digestive organs, together with " heart ", " spleen ", " lung ", and " kidney " are called the five internal organs. "Shu Wen": "Mu Zang Ye. From meat, dry sound." Classics use the original meaning, such as "Book of Ritesâ€§ Nei Ze": "Chicken liver, goose kidney, bustard Austria, deer stomach." "The thief is the sun of Fangxiu and the trooper of the Taishan Mountain, and it satiates the human liver." The original meaning of the script also uses the original meaning, such as "Mawangdui. The 14th line of the Eleven Pulses Moxibustion Classic of Foot and Arm: "Liver pain, heartache, annoyance". "Mawangdui. "Miscellaneous Remedies" Line 12: "Take the dog liver and place it in the (bee) house."

" Liver " can also be compared to the heart. For example, in Han Zou Yang's "Book from Prison": "Two masters and two ministers, dissecting the heart and believing in the liver, how can you move to the floating words!" Feeling anxious and complaining." The idioms still used in modern Chinese are "the liver and the gallbladder", "the liver and the intestines are broken", and "the liver and the brain are smeared on the ground". " Liver " is also used to express inner meaning.
humanum_short_description_en: From the sound of " meat " and " dry ", the original meaning is liver, one of the digestive organs.

From " meat" to " dry" sound, the original meaning is liver, one of the digestive organs, together with " heart", " spleen", " lung", and " kidney" are called the five internal organs. "Shu Wen": "Mu Zang Ye. From meat, dry sound." Classics use the original meaning, such as "Book of Ritesâ€§ Nei Ze": "Chicken liver, goose kidney, bustard Austria, deer stomach." "The thief is the sun of Fangxiu and the trooper of the Taishan Mountain, and it satiates the human liver." The original meaning of the script also uses the original meaning, such as "Mawangdui. The 14th line of the Eleven Pulses Moxibustion Classic of Foot and Arm: "Liver pain, heartache, annoyance". "Mawangdui. "Miscellaneous Remedies" Line 12: "Take the dog liver and place it in the (bee) house." " Liver" can also be compared to the heart. For example, in Han Zou Yang's "Book from Prison": "Two masters and two ministers, dissecting the heart and believing in the liver, how can you move to the floating words!" Feeling anxious and complaining." The idioms still used in modern Chinese are "the liver and the gallbladder", "the liver and the intestines are broken", and "the liver and the brain are smeared on the ground". " Liver" is also used to express inner meaning.

liver
Basic explanation of words
liver
gÄn
The largest digestive gland in humans or animals, it has the functions of synthesizing and storing nutrients, secreting bile, and detoxifying: the liver. hepatitis. Hepatobiliary. Liver intestines. darling.
Chinese medicine refers to one of the five internal organs: liver fire. Liver Qi.
liver
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»gÄnï¼½
["Guangyun" Gu Han cut, Ping Han, see. ]
(1) Liver. One of the human digestive organs. Together with the heart, spleen, lungs and kidneys, they are called the five internal organs.
(2) Refers to the liver of animals used as food.
(3) As a metaphor for the heart.
liver

â— Liver
liver
liver
Kangxi dictionary interpretation of words
[Not set next] [Department of meat characters] ã€€ liver; Kangxi strokes: 9; page number: page 974 09
[Tang Yun] Ancient Hanqie [Jiyun] [Yunhui] [Zhengyun] Living in the cold and dry. [Said the text] Mu Zang also. Born in wood, hidden by the soul. [Zhengzitong] The left three leaves, the right four leaves, with the bile as the house, the ninth vertebra attached to the spine is the yang center, and shaoyang leads to spring energy. Su Wen said: The liver person, the general's officer, is out of contemplation. [Release name] Liver, dry. The five elements are wood, so its body shape has branches. Everything is done with greatness. ã€PoetryÂ·DayaÂ·Or Burnt or Zhizhuanã€‘Sunburn the liver. ã€RitualÂ·Monthly Orderã€‘The sacrifice to the gate is to sacrifice the liver. ã€HuainanziÂ·Spiritual Trainingã€‘The liver is the wind.ã€€[Baihutong] The liver is a word to defend.ã€€You Liver, the name of an overseas country. Radicals: æœˆ, å¹²  (moon, dry)
Meaning Mnemonic
If the moon is dry, it's good for your liver! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."
Reading Mnemonic
As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (ã‹ã‚“) comes out! Right out of your liver.
Genghis Khan glares down at you, "You inherited my liver, and that means no moonshine for you. Protect your liver and don't drink, like me, Genghis Khan."
